utterances: And one of the things that unusual at this show this year is the number of car companies that are - have exhibits and presentations of various types.
And I have to ask you about this car that, well, totally drives itself.
It's was like being in a hunted car from some Stephen King novel.
It's called the Boss, it's a Chevy SUV that was modified by a team from Carnegie Mellon University to be an autonomous vehicle.
It was part of a government program called the DARPA Urban Challenge to create vehicles that could drive themselves.
So with radar and sonar and lasers and I think 15 computers, it can basically find its way around and just take you anywhere.
But when you're sitting in the passenger seat did you, you know, have the feeling you needed to lunge over to the empty spot over there?
Well it was eerie.
I was sitting in the quote, end quote, ""driver's seat,"" although I wasn't actually doing any driving.
I was just watching the steering wheel spin around in front of me.

And it's a pretty aggressive driving car kind a like a New York cabby, so because they had to win a race, so it takes off fast, it stops fast, it swerves around things, so it's an interesting experience.
I take it's not going to be available on the market anytime in the near future?
Well, they're saying within 10 years, which considering what a leap this is in technology that I'm - that's pretty impressive.
Let's get some listeners involved in the conversation.
Our guests are Sean Captain of Popular Science and Larry Magid who's a tech analyst for CBS News and writes for The New York Times as well.
If you'd like to join the conversation about the Consumer Electronic Show in Las Vegas, 800-989-8255, e-mail us talk@npr.org.
And Tori(ph) is on the line.
Tori is calling us from Syracuse, New York.
Hi guys.
Hi, Neal.
I'm so happy you guys are doing this show about tech stuff.
My big question, hopefully either one of your panelist can answer for me, as given Warner Brother's big announcement this week.
What's the status on high-def DVD versus Blu-ray?
And I'll take my comments off the air.
Yeah, who's going to be the Betamax here?
Well, I've actually just came from the Toshiba booth and the high-definition folks and talked to a couple of people.
I'm speaking with an official spokesperson later.
They claim they're still alive, but the buzz on the floor is that the format wars are coming to an end.
As you know, on Friday, last Friday, Warner said it will no longer be supporting HD-DVD format, which has been competing with Blu-ray.
Blu-ray currently has about 70 percent of the content, so the thought that HD-DVD could survive with just two studios and 30 percent of content is rather dim.
And most people here are predicting that the format wars are coming to an end.
Now, again, the folks that one would think would be lying in the coffin refuse to acknowledge that they're dead.
There is some possibility that they would continue to operate and people would get dual players.

There are a lot of people that have HD-DVD players that might have bought them over the holidays, but at the moment and just like within politics, sometimes the frontrunner can go behind but at the moment it seems pretty likely that the Blu-ray format is going to survive.

And in fact, the - Howard Stringer, the CEO of Sony began his talk by saying I'm feeling blue and he didn't meant that he was depressed, that meant he was elated because they are backing Blu-ray and they think that they are winning.
And so you predict though if that is what happened, those people who bought those HD-DVD players for Christmas, they're going to turn out to be junk?
Not quite.
You can watch standard definition discs from them, they're going to look great because they upscale on a high-definition DVD, so your standard def DVDs will look good.
And, right now I believe it's Paramount and University - and Universal still have contracts to produce HD-DVDs, so they will be creating content.
Maybe you'll just fall in love with Paramount and Universal titles and won't want to watch Disney or others, but look, I think that consumers benefit by this war ending.
I don't have - I don't care, personally, which one wins.
They're both fine, but it's got to win for the industry to move forward, and I think most people in the industry know that.
Most consumers know that they want to be able to go into a store, buy a player.
They want to go to another store and buy a disc or rent a disc and know that everything is going to work together.
And until that happens, I think the industry is just going to flounder around.
And there's - oh.
Go ahead.
And there's a real question about with the downloads, you know, gradually developing and getting more sophisticated.
Now, we're starting to get high-definition downloads.
I mean, it's a possibility that technology will leapfrog right over the disc.
That's what Bill Gates is saying.
He's saying, you know, he did - Bill - Microsoft is in the HDVD camp.
And so, in a sense, they're losing this war.
But he says, hey, long term, it's not going to matter because of downloads.
Bill Gates makes the - well, has made the keynote address at the Consumer Electronics Show I guess for many number of years now.
This was his last go-around, Larry.
What did he have to say?
Transferred...
Exactly.
We appreciate it.
Well, he looked back a little bit and they had a little funny video about his last day at Microsoft where he drove away in his Ford Escort.
We know Bill Gates, of course, drives a Ford Escort.
Of course, they have a partnership with Ford.
That could be why.
He talked about Microsoft's emergence as a software company outside of the PC arena, in the car with their relationship with Ford and others, in the kitchen, in the living room.
He really implied that Microsoft is moving way beyond the age of the personal computer to mobile.
Everything that you see at CES whether it's television sets or cell phones or automobiles, Microsoft wants to be running their software.
It remains to be seen how well they'll do because they don't dominate in this world they way they do in the PC arena.
But they certainly are putting a lot of money into it.

And I think that Bill Gates, as he moves into his new full-time job as a philanthropist and simply a chairperson of the Microsoft board, wants to see Microsoft evolve way beyond the personal computer.
Now, here's an e-mail question from Patrick in Kansas City.
I'd like to ask the guys at the CES whether or not they're seeing an increasing trend in devices designed to store rented media similar to Yahoo's Y!
Music Unlimited where a monthly membership fee gives you unlimited album downloads that you can put on a device or stream on your computer but which you cannot burn to disc.
This media will cease to function if you let your subscription lapse, for example.
Does this media distribution model seem to be increasing based on the devices they're seeing there?
Sean Captain?
Well, companies are proceeding with that.
Rhapsody, for example, basically a music-rental service, announced a partnership with Haier for a new device that can download directly over Wi-Fi so you don't have to be at your computer to use it.
It's called the Ibiza.
It's a pretty clever device.
And, you know, we're starting to see more in the movie realm as well.
There's a company called Voodoo.
They actually announced this a little bit before CES.
They keep the first few minutes of thousands of movies on their discs so as soon as you press play, you get the movie, and then at the background, the rest of it downloads.
So in there, you get a seamless download experience.
You're not sitting and waiting for it to happen.
And that's also for either rental or purchase service where it's locked on the disc.
So it's a kind of - it's not the same thing as just having it and being able to do it whenever you want to with it.
We're…
And there's a word that Apple is going to be doing video rentals that - once you can watch video - rented video on the iPod, which, of course, it's a huge installed base.
And we expect to hear something in Macworld that comes up in January 15th with Steve Jobs about this, assuming that the rumors are true.
Of course, Apple, one of the companies that is not - or never is - at the CES.
They have their own Macworld coming up later as Larry just mentioned.
We're talking about what's new at the Consumer Electronics Show.
Remember the days of lugging your tube TV up to your fourth floor walk up?
Wait until you see the thickness of the TVs they're showing in Vegas.
They'll make moving easy.
More on the thinner, faster and smarter in just a moment.
Stay with us.
I'm Neal Conan.
It's the TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
(Soundbite of music)
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
We're talking about CES this hour.
That's the Consumer Electronics Show, and of all the cool acronyms that are floating around the show, WiMAX has got to be the coolest.
It's supposed to be the solution to every Internet access problem you can think of; the speed of broadband, it's wireless, it's got wide coverage instead of tiny little Wi-Fi hotspots.
Any questions?
Ask our guests, Larry Magid, technology analyst for CBS News.
You can read his articles in The New York Times as well.
And Sean Captain, senior associate editor for Popular Science magazine and PopSci.com.
Both of them on the scene with us from Las Vegas.
Of course, you can join us on your phone, 800-989-8255, or by e-mail, talk@npr.org.
And let's see if we can get another caller on the line.
And this is Jim(ph).
Jim's with us from Harvard, Illinois.
Hey, good morning.

(unintelligible), being a part of the Consumer Electronics convention, what is the main tagline you're hearing from some sales people representing their products, like what kind of need are they selling the consumer on what they should have?
I think it depends on what they're selling.
What's the…
Whatever it is you needed, you know, whether you need it or not.
They think you do.
Well, is there a breakout technology this year?
Is there something that we're all going to absolutely have to have?
Or is this an incremental CES?

Well, I think going back to what Larry opened with, I mean, wireless in some form is the big news, whether it's local wireless that he talked about, whether it's WiMAX, whether it's LTE, which is another acronym that other companies will be competing with WiMAX, or whether it's mobile television.
I saw yet two more acronyms, MPH and EVSB that allow you to beam digital TV to a car and the picture doesn't break up.
It stays steady.
It looks perfect.
So everything kind of being wireless in some way.
But what we are seeing is definitely, I mean, people keep hammering away the idea of how can I get my TV to connect to my computer without the computer being there.
And I think we're making some progress.
HP had a TV.
They brought it last year called the Media Smart that basically had a wired and wireless connection to your computer.
So you could basically use it as if you have a Media Center computer in the room but it wasn't; it was somewhere else.
This year, they came out with a little box that you can plug into your TV, so any TV can have the same capability.

And I think just about everyone - Apple, Microsoft - in Apple's case, Apple TV and Microsoft through its X-box - there are probably dozens of booths here that have a wireless solution to get the data from the PC to the television.
And that seems to be the prevailing attitude right now.
Yeah.
And then speaking of wireless, also mobile phones.
I just got off the phone with Broadcom.
I'm going over there in a few minutes to look at their technology.
They have a chip, which will allow you to get 720p video, which basically means broadcast-standard, high-definition video, on a cell phone using a standard battery.
They claim the phone could run up to six hours watching video, will have a 12-megapixel camera, a high quality camcorder.
So the idea that these handheld devices, multifunction handheld mobile devices, which, of course, are radios.
They're cell phones.
But they're also television sets and television stations, so to speak.
And they claim with high-definition broadcast.
That would pretty phenomenal if reporters could be walking around with a cell phone and go live on the air with high-definition programming.
That begs the question whether the lenses are any good and plenty of other questions.
But certainly, I think mobile is continuing to evolve.
It's been at every show for the last decade or so.
But now, the convergence of mobile and multimedia is definitely real and commonplace, I think, in phones today.
Mm.
Jim, thanks for the call.
You're welcome.
Thank you.
And it sounds like from what you're saying that last year's big device, the iPhone, has certainly had an impact this year.
